metadata.title: Learn Data Science the Right Way. Ditch the atlas and jump right in 😉 | by Garrett Eichhorn | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: Learn Data Science the Right Way
metadata.description: You’d have to be living under a rock to miss out on the siren song of data science. As the “sexiest job of the 21st century” and stirring up images of AI, machine learning, magic and more, data…

outgoing_paragraph_urls.anchor_text: best computing language for data science

all_paragraphs: You’d have to be living under a rock to miss out on the siren song of data science. As the “sexiest job of the 21st century” and stirring up images of AI, machine learning, magic and more, data science is revolutionizing the ways in which we interact with information. For the casual technologist, seasoned data professional, or anyone in-between, adding data science skills to your repertoire can be very lucrative. But where should you begin?

If you’re like me, asking Google “how to learn data science” will send you into a tailspin. Articles boasting data science mastery in “8 easy steps” contradict entire PhD programs devoted to the art. Python enthusiasts and R fanatics battle it out for “best computing language for data science”, while Julia makes a foray. Database technologies tout efficient storage and retrieval methods like MySQL, Postgres, MongoDB and Cassandra to interact with bits/bytes, but differ by application. Tableau was recently purchased by SalesForce for almost $16 billion dollars, yet embedded plotting libraries and front-end frameworks make data visualization free and easy.

Because there are so many opinionated, insightful voices reverberating throughout the realm of data science, I don’t feel guilty adding just one more instrument to the orchestra. My advice? Jump in, wherever and whenever you can. There are no perfectly charted maps on this journey, only yours. Free yourself from paralysis by analysis and get your hands dirty, Baby!
… no, not that kind of dirty 🕺.

In this article, I’ll share my advice for how to ditch the atlas and jump into the wonderful world of data science. I’ll discuss my favorite open source resources, platforms and frameworks (oh my!) that can jumpstart your journey or keep the embers burning. If this time in COVID-19 quarantine has taught us anything, it’s that online education and e-learning tools have limitless potential for elevating the average technologist. There’s literally no better time to pickup a new skill or hone your hobby.
Before diving in, let’s quickly define what ‘data science’ really is:
Data Scientist (n.): Person who is better at statistics than any software engineer and better at software engineering than any statistician. — Josh Wills via Twitter

Regardless of how you feel about this definition, it illustrates the aura of ambiguity that surrounds data science. How much statistics does the average software engineer really know? How many engineering projects has the average statistician worked on? Personally, I don’t think it matters. The field is constantly shifting to include new technologies, obsoleting outdated ones, and encouraging burgeoning domains to join the party. So as long as you are committed to the pursuit of learning and building, I believe you’re well on your way.

Still don’t believe me? Take a look at any number of job postings for data science, and you’ll find basic requirements ranging from PhD in advanced algorithm design to anyone with a HS diploma and relevant experience. 10 years of project-based work using specific technology combats another posting for an entry level, college graduate with a degree in mathematics. Fluency in Python, R, Scala, COBOL, etc. versus anyone with experience embracing ambiguity using code.
I recently went to a conference where the brilliant Dick De Veaux used this diagram (or one similar) to convey his definition for data science.

Professor De Veaux used terms like ‘predictive analytics’, ‘machine learning’, ‘data science’ and ‘artificial intelligence’ interchangeably, justifying his loose nomenclature with funny examples that prove just how nebulous the subject can be. I like this diagram because it leaves room for agility and movement: if you’re comfortable with one subject, simply delve into another.

I definitely don’t mean to nullify the awesome accomplishments of those data scientists out there with advanced degrees and relevant experience. However, I do want to inspire the growing number of curious data professionals to build their confidence and lean-in with some great resources. Let’s take a look!👇
I’m not being 💰 to promote any of these resources, and I hope you find real value in using my recommendations to upgrade your data science skills!

There are immense resources available for anyone interested in jumpstarting or sustaining a career in data science. Among the plethora of online courses, gamified curriculums, GitHub repositories and Medium articles, here are a few of my favorites:

This brilliant platform queries their user community to crowdsource and aggregate courses on various topics, including data science and machine learning, to deliver free online learning. Depending on your skill level and interest in particular subjects, you can tailor search queries and/or join their community to receive updates on new offerings.

The Internet Archive offers free books, movies, software, music, websites, and more on virtually every subject. A colleague of mine recently suggested the Internet Archive to fill up some quarantine time, and I haven’t looked back! You can download and/or checkout high caliber ML / AI textbooks to continue your research or dive into new topics.

Python is by far my favorite programming language, due to its simplicity and boundless community support, and I’m always surprised by the quality Python resources offered for free. Python is a great language to introduce programming concepts if you’re new to the field; if you’re a veteran, learning or refreshing the Python fundamentals will only improve your marketability.
Although I haven’t stepped through all of the free courses listed below (and neither should you!), these are some of the most popular and highly rated resources deserving of your attention 📚.

I keep a 1TB external hard drive with me at all times, chock full of programming textbooks, PDF’s, cheat sheets, and more. Although it’s outdated, especially with such easy access to the cloud, I like having everything organized on a physical drive. Can’t explain it. Anyway, many of the 📖 👇 are on my 💾.

If you’ve ever taken an online programming course, you might’ve been frustrated by the disconnect between browser-based code and actual development environments. Swirl teaches you R programming and data science interactively, at your own pace, and right in the R console. All you need to do is download R, setup RStudio, install swirl, and get started! As someone infinitely more comfortable with Python, this tool has really helped me expand my horizons and comfortability with RStudio (a preferred IDE for R developers).

If you haven’t used GitHub before, git started 😉! For those independent data scientists out there building cool automation scripts / ML projects, GitHub offers a great place to store and share your code. If you work on a team, chances are you’ve used similar tools to collaborate and manage production code. GitHub is the online platform (although a desktop application can be downloaded) for creating repositories and sharing code; git lives in your terminal and communicates with GitHub much more efficiently.

For newcomers I recommend Git Started with GitHub for a crash-course into the basics, including installation. If you’re familiar with GitHub but want to get more acquainted with the terminal, checkout this Bash Shell Tutorial to learn more efficient command-line essentials. For browser-based scenarios focused on version control, try katacoda. If you want to skip the tutorial and move straight to scripting, check out this reference guide:
And if all of this looks a bit rudimentary and you’re simply looking for a refresher / cheat sheet to use at your disposal, clone this repository.

If you’ve ever seen MTV Cribs, then this reference is for you: an IDE (Integrated Development Environment), much like the master bedroom, is where the magic happens. Regardless on your language(s) of choice, your IDE really sets the mood for any professional or personal code development and should be customized to fit your unique coding needs. Data science projects rely on multiple languages, frameworks and platforms working together seamlessly; I recommend Visual Studio Code to streamline your operation. They have a fantastic how-to guide for effective data science set-up 👇.

You may also be interested in Docker for containerizing development environments. If you plan on building and sharing code, but Docker isn’t quite what you’re looking for, I highly recommend software like Kubernetes or Anaconda Cloud.
Pro-tip: if you have a few minutes to spare, spend 12 minutes learning Docker basics and level-up your next project.

Data visualization is a critical component of any data science deployment, responsible for converting data insights into consumable observations. All your hard work extracting, cleaning and modeling data might be wasted with a bad visualization; conversely, a great viz can catalyze actionable insights and build trust, invoke curiosity, invigorate projects, and so much more.

Tableau makes it easy to arrange beautiful metrics, limited only by your imagination. Having trouble feeling inspired? Take a look at their “Viz of the Day”. If you’re new to Tableau, they have some awesome resources for quickly ramping up on their platform.

As of April 2020, Tableau Desktop (paid version) is offering a 90 day trial to augment your skills. Tableau Desktop, and Tableau Prep which is also included, offers a much wider array of data connections, embeddings, pipelining, etc.
If you’re already an avid Tableau user, check out the Zen Masters (identical twin brothers, obviously) and get ready to have your socks knocked off.

Looking for pertinent resources to help you navigate a technical interview? LeetCode provides hands-on training for enhancing skills and expanding your realm of expertise. An omniscient “Online Judge” provides immediate feedback on the strength and efficiency of your algorithms to facilitate a customized experience. I use LeetCode to prepare for those data science interviews where live coding or pseudo-code is required. They have a premium version with slightly better UX and more tailored interview questions, organized by company.
If you can swing it, these resources are cheap and immersive. These are a few of the investments I’ve made, and refer to them constantly when approaching new projects and/or working with students.

Humble Bundle is a digital storefront that offers different collections of games, software, e-books, etc. for CHEAP. Their goal is to democratize development earnings and contribute to charity, while delivering “awesome content to customers at great prices”. They’ll usually have thousands of dollars worth of machine learning / AI textbooks bundled for less than $20. Yes, you heard that right. Basically, you get to choose what to pay and how much should go to developer, charity, etc. Checkout their current offering:

Learn data science from the comfort of your browser! DataCamp is expansive and constantly adding new courses / skills to their curriculum. You can choose different career tracks rooted in Python, R and SQL, following along with industry experts to complete projects at variable scale. When you complete a free trial, you can usually grab an exceptional re-marketing deal by making them sweat a bit before purchasing — I got 60% off via email offer by waiting a few days to purchase the annual package. Also, you’ll get a badge you can add to your LinkedIn profile once you finish a career track 🙌.
Pro-tip: take a look at the DataCamp free cheat sheets — they’re well organized and worth keeping close during technical interviews and coding challenges.

This book offers more than just Python skills for beginners — it refines your relationship with logic. Reimagine mundane tasks and start processing “stuff” with a logician’s lens using Python basics. I literally recommend this book to every non-technical Manager / Director / VP I work with for an immediate boost.

Once you feel more comfortable flexing your data science muscles, you’ll probably want to communicate and share with other like-minded technologists. GitHub, Medium, StackOverflow and others are fantastic places to start connecting with people, but might leave you craving more professional, curated content. Enter ACM, or the Association for Computing Machinery, offering membership to “the world’s largest educational and scientific computing society”. It’s like the Toastmasters for data science.
You can also visit their digital library, which is included in the cost of membership, to search for relevant resources in any computing subject.

This is at the top-end of paid resources, so if you’re new to data science or can keep busy with the other courses and textbooks I’ve referenced, it’s probably in your best interest to hold off. That being said, if you’re an academic or desperate for cutting-edge references — this is definitely for you!
Pro-tip: Safari Online Learning is included as a perk of ACM membership! So if you’re looking to maximize your dollar, ACM membership is the way to go.

Expedited programming bootcamps boasting saturated curricula are taking the world by storm. Chances are, if you’ve been researching data science and perusing online courses, you’ve come across a bootcamp or two that offer to quickly boost your data science status from zero to hero. But are bootcamps worth the price-tag?

I argue it’s more about the journey than the destination, but I’m biased. I work as a Teaching Assistant (T.A) for a prominent Data Analytics / Data Science Bootcamp here in Minneapolis, MN, focused on empowering students with bleeding-edge technical skills. It’s definitely a “mile-wide, meter-thick” approach to the multi-faceted world of data science. We cover so many relevant topics along the way (6 month cycles) that it forces each student to embrace ambiguity and focus on their problem-solving approach instead of finding the “perfect” solution. And that’s because there are no perfect solutions for problems that are constantly shifting, only solutions that work efficiently, beautifully and sustainably with room to grow.

It’s not for everyone. But if you put in the effort and commit yourself to learning, you’ll gain invaluable skills, a dedicated project portfolio, open-source tools to tackle any problem, and confidence to boot. Pretty awesome stuff in my opinion.

I’ll step off my soapbox and recommend Trilogy Education: they offer an array of bootcamp options that can be completed part-time or full-time. Before you spend any money — ask to audit a class, check out the full curriculum, speak with a past student and/or professor, etc. to get a better idea of what ROI you can expect.

To re-iterate: these bootcamps make money because most of us don’t have the resources to build and vet our own immersive curriculum. If you want an expedited journey, chock full of supplemental resources and support to keep you motivated, then a bootcamp might be the right option.

Since you’re reading this article, you’re already well acquainted with Medium. Give yourself a pat on the back! I found Medium somewhat serendipitously and was *shocked* by the breadth and depth of publications. If you haven’t already, become a member and update your preferences so that Medium can provide you with great custom content.

My favorite publication on Medium is Towards Data Science. It’s been a personal goal of mine to get published @here, so I’m quite proud to have been vetted their publication staff and approved. If you have something interesting to say or simply too much time on your hands, put pen to paper…or fingers to keyboard? I was but a long-time connoisseur before I worked up the courage to send my content out into the world, and I haven’t looked back.
Here are a few relevant publications I like:
Pro-tip: if you feel comfortable with your online presence, but want to stay up-to-date with frequent, low-maintenance content, read Nat Torkington’s daily collection of 4 Short Links.

You can’t be a data scientist without access to data. If you’re lucky enough to have corporate data available and approved, go for it! Otherwise, there’s no shame in analyzing cleaned-up, public data before moving using secure, private data.

I work in the tech industry as a data science consultant. I honestly believe there’s no better environment for learning new technologies, methodologies and strategy than from experts in the private sector. Personally, I communicate and interview with recruiters / companies as much as possible to strengthen my soft skills and expand my network.
If you have any interest in connecting with me to discuss, drop me a line on LinkedIn. I’d love to connect!

Data science is simply too nebulous to build the perfect roadmap for success. As requirements evolve, so will you, to embrace the emerging technology, methodology, strategy and personality that defines the industry. There’s always an opportunity to explore and advance, pushing your boundaries to incorporate another tool into the proverbial tool-belt.
The outlined resources are enough to jumpstart your data science journey. If you’re further along, they should be helpful to invigorate or point you in a new direction.
All of the content in this article is heavily influenced by my students and fellow instructional staff. A huge shoutout to them for inspiring me to continue learning, especially now!
If you have any suggestions for resources you’d like me to add, I’d love to hear from you in the comments below. Thanks for reading!
Your home for data science. A Medium publication sharing concepts, ideas and codes.
